Source Text: 2BR02B
Everything was perfectly swell.
So was old age.
Death, barring accidents, was an adventure for volunteers.
The population of the United States was stabilized at forty-million souls.
One bright morning in the Chicago Lying-in Hospital, a man named Edward K. Wehling, Jr., waited for his wife to give birth.

Source Text: He was the only man waiting.
Not many people were born a day any more.

Source Text: Wehling was fifty-six, a mere stripling in a population whose average age was one hundred and twenty-nine.
X-rays had revealed that his wife was going to have triplets.
Young Wehling was hunched in his chair, his head in his hand.

Source Text: His camouflage was perfect, since the waiting room had a disorderly and demoralized air, too.
The floor was paved with spattered dropcloths.
The room was being redecorated.
A sardonic old man, about two hundred years old, sat on a stepladder, painting a mural he did not like.
Back in the days when people aged visibly, his age would have been guessed at thirty-five or so.
Aging had touched him that much before the cure for aging was found.

Source Text: The mural he was working on depicted a very neat garden.

Source Text: The orderly looked in at the mural and the muralist.

He gave a satiric smile.

"That's good of Dr. Hitz," said the orderly.
He was referring to one of the male figures in white, whose head was a portrait of Dr. Benjamin Hitz, the hospital's Chief Obstetrician.

What's the name?"
"Wehling," said the waiting father, sitting up, red-eyed and frowzy.
"Edward K. Wehling, Jr., is the name of the happy father-to-be."
He raised his right hand, looked at a spot on the wall, gave a hoarsely wretched chuckle.
"Oh, Mr. Wehling," said Dr. Hitz, "I didn't see you."
"The invisible man," said Wehling.
"They're all fine, and so is the mother. I'm on my way in to see them now."
"Hooray," said Wehling emptily.
"What man in my shoes wouldn't be happy?" said Wehling.
He gestured with his hands to symbolize care-free simplicity.

Do you know what a drupelet is, Mr. Wehling?" said Hitz.
